title: Wizards game against Chinese team draws Hong Kong supporters
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Former NBPA Executive Director Charles Grantham lends his expertise while dissecting the situation between the NBA and China that has dominated the headlines in recent days. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON — The Washington Wizards' Capital One Arena sits in the heart of the city’s Chinatown, which served as a unique backdrop to the chasm between the NBA and China over Houston Rockers general manager Daryl Morey’s pro-Hong Kong tweet, which infuriated China.

On Wednesday, the Wizards played the Chinese Basketball Association’s Guangzhou Loong Lions in a preseason game.

Outside the arena about an hour before the game, pro-Hong Kong supporters from the non-profit Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation handed out "Free Hong Kong" t-shirts, hoping fans would wear them inside the arena.

It was a sparse crowd at the game — no more than a few thousand fans — but some fans wore the t-shirts.

Pro-Hong Kong supporters out the Wizards arena, where China’s Loong Lions are in town for a preseason game. They’re handing out shirts hoping fans where them inside the arena, which is in the heart of D.C.’s Chinatown. pic.twitter.com/04VqnrN5a5 — Jeff Zillgitt (@JeffZillgitt) October 9, 2019

One fan at the end of the Chinese national anthem yelled "Free Hong Kong" and then left the arena on his own. He was not escorted out, according to Wizards spokesperson Scott Hall. Jon Schweppe, who was wearing a pro-Hong Kong shirt, confirmed this account.

A few other fans had "Free Hong Kong" signs, and Schweppe, wearing one of those t-shirts, held a sign that read "Google Uyghurs," a reference to Muslims who are under mass internment in China.

At the end of the Chinese national anthem and during the silence before the singing of the Star Spangled Banner, a protestor screams “Free Hong Kong!” while holding a sign. He walks out of the arena peacefully, followed by an usher. pic.twitter.com/H9JrZHb9FO — Candace Buckner (@CandaceDBuckner) October 9, 2019

Those signs were removed by arena staffers because Capital One Arena has a policy that says signs, banners and posters "may not be commercial or political in nature." Lions players were not made available to reporters after the game.

But those in support of Hong Kong were able to make their point.

"We clearly understand Chinese influence on major American industries or corporations or people," Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation executive director Marion Smith told USA TODAY Sports. "But at the same time, we think it’s the long-term and medium-term interest of America and the NBA for us to resist all efforts of the Chinese communist party to use a sport to advance propaganda."

While Smith understands the NBA side of this issue may not last long, Smith noted his organization, which has been around since 1992, is in this for the long haul.

CLOSE NBA Commissioner Adam Silver said the league wasn't apologizing for Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey's since-deleted tweet showing support for anti-government protesters in Hong Kong. (Oct. 8) AP, AP

"We are interested in business, sports and entertainment leaders understanding that we need companies that enjoy American free speech, rule of law and free enterprise and to stand for those values," Smith said. "Increasingly, companies and public figures are going to have to make a choice here."

After a slow start to its defense of Morey, the NBA and commissioner Adam Silver made clear their support for free speech, even if it cuts into the NBA's revenue from China.

Smith shot down the idea that it’s a difficult decision for companies to walk away from the amount of money that can be made from China.

"You can turn a buck, people do it all over the world. But there’s business and then there’s business," he said. "When it comes to free enterprise — a system that respects the dignity of work and human rights of the individual — that’s what we stand for."

Follow Jeff Zillgitt on Twitter @JeffZillgitt.
description: Supporters from the non-profit Victims of Communism Memorial Foundation handed out "Free Hong Kong" t-shirts at Capital One Arena in DC's Chinatown.
